Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Preoperative Preparation and Anesthesia for Trabeculectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised controlled trial was conducted with participants eligible for trabeculectomy.

Participants.evidence: Participants eligible for trabeculectomy. The study was set in a tertiary ophthalmic center.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either subconjunctival-intracameral anesthesia without sedation or a comparator anesthesia technique.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the impact of preoperative preparation and anesthesia choice on trabeculectomy outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the success rate of trabeculectomy, measured over a 12-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a higher success rate (mean difference = 5.2%, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3/100 (3%) of the intervention group and 1/98 (1%) of the control group, with mild complications.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Eye Institute.
